Description: Restored North Ionian black-figured pottery hemispherical bowl; handles seemingly modern; exterior: frieze of uprights at lip; two animal friezes separated by band of meander hooks between bands; upper frieze has floral at handle join, a sphinx to right and parts of two geese facing left, in black-figure; goats running right, heads reverted, in lower frieze; below, wavy line between bands and lower frieze of alternating rosettes and sets of verticals.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The vessel was presumably restored at the British Museum prior to being shipped to Boston.
Bibliographic references: Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 216, no. 49)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 105, pl. XXXIII, no. 313)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.324)
Walter-Karydi 1973 / Samische Gefässe des 6. Jahrhunderts vor Christi: Landschaftsstile ostgriechischer Gefässe (no. 1016, pl. 125)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.6221 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
